commit_list.message:
Terrain Materials

Added the ability to select the material coloring of the terrain area.
Colorings are interpolated like terrain characteristics (although in a
different manner, since the color cannot be determined until the value
is calculated).
Imported Tuple implementation.
Changed the Script Execution Order for safer component initializations.
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
Added functionality to AverageHeight slider

Changed the value calculation job to take into account the average
height of the terrain area, and implemented the UI slider to control it.
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
v1.2

- Map implementation with a Texture2D. User draws in that texture with
the color of the area that they want to draw.
- Map has fixed dimensions now, and player can’t go away out of the
borders of the map.
- Each point of the terrain is now calculated with the characteristics
of the terrain area it belongs to.
- Values in the borders between areas are interpolated so there are no
abrupt changes in the landscape.
- Several optimizations in the value calculation threaded job.
- Moved all auxiliar functions to a separate class.
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
v1.2-development-2.0

TL;DR: Terrain Area creation and selection
- Created the system of adding new terrain areas
- Created the assets for terrain area selection
- Selecting an area makes the editor’s sliders alter that area’s
characteristics
- Minor: Changed all used Hashtables to Dictionaries, since their use
is recommended as Hashtables are deprecated in some platforms (as well
as Lists in favor of ArrayLists)
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
v1.2-development-1.0

- Definition of v1.2 goal: the map is brush painted to create different
areas, each one with its own terrain characteristics.
- Changes to editor UI design to allow area creation and edition
- Major architecture overhaul to allow area management
- Slight tweaks to player camera
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
1.1.1

Now not only loads the chunk the player is in, but also the surrounding
ones so no empty spots appear in the screen.
Added an invalidation mechanism so only the central chunks are
recalculated upon editions, and the recalculation of further chunks is
postponed until the player visits them.
ChunkLoaded is now attached to the player. This allows getting its
position without needing a reference to the player.
commit_list.repo_description: Procedural Terrain Generation - Internship and Final Degree Project

commit_list.message:
v1.1

Major. Changed the terrain system from single mesh to chunk-based level
streaming.

Initial version

Basic terraforming controls and navigation. Single mesh system, which
recalculates its values on every change (considering changing to chunk
loading streamer)

commit_list.message:
Use normalized RGB space for classification

Using normalized RGB space for the classification of pixels removes the
luminosity in their colors. This makes a color the same regardless of
shadows or bright spots, which enhances image classification in extreme
lighting situations.

commit_list.message:
Fixed some NN training issues

- Inputs are now applied the sigmoid function, meaning that every input
range is valid, since it is then transformed into [0, 1]
- Fixed a bug where the delta for the last layer wasn't using the
derivative of the activation function.
- Fixed a bug where the delta for each layer was using applying the
derivative of the activation function to the activation values instead
of the weighted sums.

commit_list.message:
Merge pull request #1 from agarzonp/setting-up-environment

Setting up environment
Initial commit
Implemented control point creation + deletion
Added spline control points translation

Added an animation for the spline

Added an animated point through the spline (also displaying the
tangent). This will later be changed by the actual position and
orientation of the camera.

Changed spline rendering architecture

Spline rendering is now performed by the spline class.
The points that form the spline are only calculated once, instead of
every render.

Fixed bspline calculation

Corrected the generation of the first and last sections of the bspline
Implemented bspline calculation
Draw control points too

Added simple spline calculation

For now, spline is calculated as a cubic bezier curve of 4 control
points
Added initial spline infrastructure

Merge pull request #5 from parmandorc/splineCam-states

Different states (FreeCam, SplineEditor and FollowSpline) and different camera types(Free, FollowSpline, FPS)

Merge pull request #7 from parmandorc/spline-2

Advanced spline rendering

Added explicit rendering of all the spline points

Added the possibility to render all the points that are used to draw the
curve.

Improved adaptive sampling tests

Added a new test to adaptive sampling that ensures long almost-straight
sections are rendered correctly.
If the true value of the middle point of a segment is at a greater
distance from the rendered segment, perform further sampling.
Changed render colors for spline

Created parameters to control quality of curve

Adaptive sampling can now be controlled with a few parameters.
Implemented adaptive sampling for spline rendering

Revert "Preparation for adaptive sampling"

This reverts commit bfba329dff3ef831a2a77fcde03d3d4556e449ee.

This preparation work was meant for the use of the Casteljau algorithm for adaptive sampling using recursive subdivision. However, b-splines don't follow exactly the Casteljau algorithm, but the de Boor algorithm, which is more complicated. Hence, this preparation work is not needed.
Preparation for adaptive sampling

Merge pull request #10 from parmandorc/make-great-scene

Make great scene(at least I tried...)

Merge pull request #4 from parmandorc/pr/2

Camera
Fixed previous conflict resolution
Merge branch 'master' into orientation
Implemented custom orientation edition
Fixed a bug in control point creation
Draw custom orientations
Smoothed custom orientation interpolation
Added orientation to spline camera positions

Merge pull request #9 from parmandorc/persistent-spline-between-states

Create the singleton SplineManager so many states can get the splines. The SplineManager is initialised in SplineCam

Merge pull request #6 from parmandorc/follow-spline

Follow spline and camera rotation using quaternions

Merge pull request #11 from parmandorc/final-controls

Final controls

Made animation speed const

Animation through the spline is now uniform with respect to the spline's
length - the traveling speed is constant.
Before, the animation would travel in a constant time from frame 0 to 1,
so it was fast for big splines and really slow for small ones.

Implemented cyclic bspline

Spline can now be cyclic in addition to clamped
Capped game loop time

Fixed a bug in spline rendering

Fixed a bug that caused to draw infinite points in a spline section that
was defined by 4 points that are the same point.

Implemented camera point focus

Added the possibility to focus the camera either on the currently
selected control point or the animated point.

Implmeneted camera position recording

User can create a spline control point with the current position and
orientation of the camera.
Added play controls to follow spline camera
Fixed a bug in control point deletion
Refactored spline initialization

Changed edition of control points

Moving a control points now does so in the axis relative to the camera,
instead of global axis.

Changed control point creation

Control points are now created at the position of the animation's
current position rather than duplicated the currently selected control
point.
Changed editor controls
Allow spline rendering during camera animation
Don't move camera when editing control point
Added user controls to readme
Added video demo to readme
Added team contribution to readme

Merge pull request #10 from eliodeberardinis/Elio_Room_Customization_1_1_17

Add decorations to the rooms
Added report to the README
Preparatory work for room decorations.
Added instructions to install the NumPy library

Merge pull request #9 from eliodeberardinis/collision-optimization

Collision optimization

Added perfomance test results for the numpy optimization.

The results show that, even though there is an overhead of using numpy arrays that show little improvement for simple executions (possibly worse results for really easy dungeons), the improvements in execution time are considerable (+50%) for bigger and more complex dungeons.

Optimized collision system using the Numpy library.

Optimized the computation of the AABB-optimized collision system to use array operations in the numpy library. This way, all calculations for a collision check can be computed in one big operation instead of using a loop.

Made a class for the collision system.

This will allow for further optimizations and better handling of the collision system.

Added performance test results for AABB-optimized collisions.

Performed a set of tests to gather data about the performance improvements of the new optimized collision system, which has proven to reduce execution times by over 90%, and over 99% for complex dungeons (high iterations and difficulty).

Fixed a bug in the collision system's math.

The getBBPoints method was not obtaining correctly the vectors of expansion (they were being rotated in the opposite angle).
This was already fixed in #6, but the fix was reverted by mistake in #7.

Refactored code for both collision systems.

Refactored AABB collision detection methods so both the complex and optimized methods can use the same code efficiently.

Added an optimized AABB collision detection.

Implemented a way to use an optimized collision system based on all AABBs in case all tiles are using square angles.

Simplified check collision and adding process.

Checking if a tile collides with the previously place tiles automatically adds the new tile to the collision system.
This is preparatory work for optimizations in the collision system.

Merge pull request #8 from eliodeberardinis/code-cleanup

Module code cleanup

Cleaned up module references.

Changed modules from classes with all static methods to just modules with regular methods.
Cleaned up references to methods in modules.
Added python compiled files to gitignore
Added references two module files in the project file.

Merge pull request #6 from eliodeberardinis/corridor-generation

Added the final rules for corridor generation, using weighted probabilities.
Corridors also backtrack when failed to place a tile, resuming generation from a previous point (without retrying the options that had already been tried).
Generation can be performed using any of the widths of the tiles, respecting what tiles match each other.

Added different sizes to corridors.

Corridors can be generated now with different sizes (to match the exit point of the previous room).
Corridors also have a chance of changing their width mid-way for higher difficulties.
Fixed a bug with the connection width of wide ramp tiles.

Preparation work for different-sized corridors.

Added data necesarry for tile management for generation of size-changing corridors.

Fixed issues in collision system.

Made tile's height more accurate.
Fixed a bug in ramp tiles data.
Fixed a bug in the collision system, where the getBBPoints method was not obtaining correctly the vectors of expansion (they were being rotated in the opposite angle).
Added corridor characteristics depending on difficulty.
Implemented corridor length depending on difficulty.

Added backtracking to corridor generation.

Implemented simple backtracking when all alternatives failed when placing a tile in the generation of a corridor.
The last element of the corridor will be removed, and generation will resume from the point it ended (it will not retry the already explored options)

Added weighted probabilities for tiles in corridors.

Tiles are now selected with a weighted chance.
Generator retries with all alternatives when placing a tile before failing.

Merge pull request #5 from eliodeberardinis/backtracking

Simple backtracking

Added simple backtracking.

When a room fails to be placed, the generator will retry iteratively by removing each time the last tile of the previous path (it will not remove tiles other than those from the path that leads to the problematic room).

Backtracking preparation work

- Failing to place a room now stops generating the dungeon, and properly does not create the door to that room.
- The buildPath function now return a sequence of path transform, which will allow to retake the dungeon generation from previous points.

Merge pull request #2 from eliodeberardinis/collision-system

Added a collision system for checking tile overlapping.
Completed collision data for all tiles.

Completed collision system

Added the structure that keeps track of the previously placed tiles against which to test collision.

Added collision test between BB's

Implemented a way to check if two Bounding Boxes are overlapping. The BB's don't have to be axis aligned (AABB), so the method uses the Separating Axis Theorem to perform the test.
Completed comments for documentation

Merge pull request #1 from eliodeberardinis/tree-generation

Tree generation

Fixed a typo in the initial number of expansions

(This doesn't have an actual effect in execution, but is now correct).

Allowed branching of the tree since the first iteration.

Added the possibility to the spawn room to branch into several paths directly, instead of always having one path to one room which then can branch out.

Implemented early termination for branches in the graph

Added the possibility that a branch in the tree stops expanding as long as at least one branch reaches the maximum number of iterations.
Implemented tree generation for more than one branch
Started dungeon generation using a generated graph
Implemented graph generation for easy/linear dungeon
Fixed a missing door in the example scene.
Implemented concatenation for 3-way and 4-way joint tiles.

Fixed the example dungeon.

Fixed some doors that were exposing the exterior between hallways of different sizes.

Implemented concatenation for more tiles.

Implemented the concatenation for all 2-way tiles (3 and 4 way tiles to do).

Implemented tile concatenation.

Implemented a way to keep on adding tiles from the current position and rotation.

Test 3 now displays a box for the player

Added a box with the size of a player following convention (128x32
units), in order to have a sense of the size of the dungeon.

Tested how to make a composite scene

Tested how to create a scene using several tiles and placing them
correctly.
Test 1 now displays the index of each tile

Tested how to copy one specific mesh

Tested how to copy all the information from one specific mesh to another
fbx file.
Test 1 now displays the names of the nodes

Tested load and save fbx

Tested basic fbx functions for loading and saving a scene with the fbx
sdk.
Added custom banner & logo

Made spawn rate scale with number of players

Made the spawn rate of particles scale with the number of players, so
games with more players have more action.

Fixed a bug with thrust particles in game over

Fixed a bug that caused the thrust particles of players to keep playing
during the game over, where everything else is frozen.

Fixed a bug with destroyed particles and scores

Fixed a bug that caused a player to not have its scored decremented if one
of its particles was destroyed before it got out of range.

Tweaked player input controls

Changed the move forward mapping to the left click, since it's more
user-intuitive.
Project Settings
Tweaked glass dome material

Tweaked game forces

Balanced the forces of all gameplay elements to be more appealing.
In the case of the player, this also serves with how easy it is to
control.

Balanced the vortex mechanic

Made the vortex appear less times, as it is meant to be a high-impact rare
situation the player has to face, just to break the monotony of the rest
of the game. Before it happened to often, and you had no time to play the
game outside of trying to hide from the vortex.
Added how to play images
Added game logo
Minor UI changes

Added how to play instructions

Added basic architecture and text for game instructions.

Added net sync for thrust particles

Implemented network synchronization of player thrust particles.
Since clients have authority over their local player, and we cannot
directly send an RPC to the other clients, a Command needs to be sent to
the server, who's then able to send call the RPC.

Added thrust particles

Added particles when the player is moving forward. This helps readability
on player input.
TODO: make the thrust particles synched over the network (see thrust
particles of other players - currently you can only see your own
player's).

Added camera shake during vortex

This helps clarity and readability to this high-impact gameplay element.
This will be furtherly enhanced with sound effects if time permits it.

Added shadows

Added shadows to player and particles, for more appealing visual effects.

Added timer bar

Added a progress bar for the game time. This helps clarity in gameplay,
specially in knowing when the next vortex is coming.

Fixed a bug with ingame score indicator in clients

Fixed a bug that caused the score indicator to be delayed by one unit in
clients. This is because the RPC method is being called before the
SyncVars are transmitted across the network. Instead of this, SyncVarHooks
are now used. However, one must remember to manually assign the values in
the hook methods - otherwise, it won't work.

Added Score screen

Added a screen that shows the score for each player when the game ends.

Fixed player's rotation sync across the network

Fixed the syncrhonization of the players' rotation across the network,
since it wasn't synching properly.
Particles' rotation synching is kept as before as gameplay doesn't require
the overhead of synching them.

Fixed a bug in Deposit script

Fixed a bug that caused the DraggedByVortex component not to be re-enabled
after the particle exits the deposit.

Added in-game score indicators

Added indicators above each player with their score during the game.
This helps with clarity in gameplay.

Finished UI style

Finished colors and UI design elements.
Added font.
Added background music
Added textures for arena walls

Tweaked arena floor material

Made floor more metallic.
Added textures for metal protectors
Added map floor texture

Fixed a bug in player leaving lobby

Fixed a bug that caused a non-host player to trigger Game Over check when
leaving the lobby (this check should only happen during the game).
Handle disconnection with host

Fixed a bug when failed to join a game

Sometimes, a connections is created very briefly before the server refuses
a client (because of game full or started). To consistently handle this
cases, client checks for a few frames that it has joined the game (that
the connections is active and stable).

Implemented Lobby

Games now start with a lobby, and players can join while the lobby is
open. When the host starts the game, players will no longer be able to
join.
Full lobbies (already 4 players) will also reject new connections.
Made ScrollingTextures still during GameOver

Implemented the custom Network HUD

Changed the implementation of the NetworkHUD from Unity's one to a custom
implemenetation that fits better the existing UI architecture of the game.

Fixed screen aspect ratio to 1:1

Fixed camera's aspect ratio to square 1:1 for gameplay reasons:
map is square and it is not wanted that the scene is rendered outside that
square.
Added final textures for portals
Added final model and materials for player
Added final models & materials for particles

Added GameOver detection upon player death

When a player dies, their client will show the Defeat UI screen, while
remaining in the game scene as an observer.
When only one player stands, they are proclaimed as victors.
Fixed some issues with Server/Client disconnections and the synching of
this to other game instances in the network.

Added player colors

Each player has a different color, which matches their assigned deposit.
Added Particles to Vortex

Added VFX for blach hole

Added to the scene the Projector that simulates the black hole.

Added blackhole gaussian effect

Created a tool for creating radial gaussian gradient texture images. Used
for creating a texture for the black hole.

Added VFX for dome

Added lightning bolts to the central dome
Refactored dome handling to be more effective.

Documentation

Completed some comments for documentation.
Made line endings and some other coding-style elements consistent.

Objects inside deposits are not dragged by vortex

'Repelled' objects are not affected by the vortex if inside an active
deposit (if a deposit does not have an assigned player, objects will be
dragged by the vortex even if they appear to be inside).
Added network awareness to corner deposits so the clients don't try
applying the DraggedByVortex force, which is then corrected by the server's
authority, but makes the objects vibrate.

Overhauled score system

Changed the architecture for the tracking of score, so it updates as the
game progresses (helpful for displaying the current score during the game in the
future).
Added the second type of score: a player can also earn points by placing
'repelled' units in their assigned corner.

Changed player controls

Player object now faces at the direction of the cursor, and the player can
right click (or press Space) to thrust forwards.
This is more intuitive as it works better with the rest of all the force-based
gameplay.
Added randomness to object spawn

Changed RandomStartPosition to polar coordinates

The component RandomStartPosition now selects a position between to radius
from the origin.
Added geometry & basic behaviour for central dome
Added main level geometry

Implemented vortex mechanic

With long cooldown times, a vortex is opened that drags all objects
towards itself, destroying them when reaching its centre.
This is meant as a high-impact mechanic in the game that breaks the
monotony of the rest of the mechanics, bringing an element of danger to
the game, as players can be destroyed this way too (the only way a player
can die in the game).

Tweaked gameplay of magnetized units

For gameplay design reasons, repelled units do not need to flock, whereas
attracted units do, although they just use the separation component (the
group that follows the player needs to not collapse, but it is not wanted
that boids start flocking or forming groups on their own).

Added victory/defeat of players

The player with the highest score at the end of the game will win.
Score is given by the highest number of 'attractive' active objects for
each player.

Added game duration

Games now last for a set amount of time.
When the end of the game is reached, the scene is frozen and players
cannot move.
Merged multiplayer_impl into master

Added network awareness to some components

Added network awareness to a few components, which were having some issues
with synchronization across the network, causing clients without authority
to see some object sweep their position (since they were being assigned a
position by said client, then having it overriden by the correct
position).

Tuned network transforms' parameters

After thorough testing, tweaked the values of the different parameters of
the NetworkTransform components, so that all the objects are synced
correctly, with as little warping as possible.

Implemented multiplayer for spawned objects

Added network awareness to spawned magnetized objects.
In order for the GameManager to be able to spawn the objects across the
network, its instance needs to be a NetworkIdentity. However, a
NetworkManager object cannot have that component. Consequently, the two
components (GameManager and NetworkManager) have been separated in two
different GameObjects.
Furthermore, with the GameManager being a NetworkIdentity, its state is
handled by the NetworkManager, and so it will be disabled while the game
is not connected. Therefore, there is no need for a paused|playing state,
since the Update function will not be called when the GameManager is
disabled (when there is no active game).
The MagnetizedByPlayer has been expanded for its use in multiplayer
(objects will be magnetized by the closest player).

Made arena's size fixed

If the game is going to be multiplayer, it doesn't make sense to have the
arena's size be calculated depending on the camera's aspect ratio (which
would be the host's). However, instead of deleting the class and replacing
all the references in the code base, it is better to keep the class to
have a central place from where to still get the arena's width and height.
Added network awareness to player

Created basic multiplayer architecture

Added a NetworkManager to the Game scene, and a NetworkManagerHUD to the
UI scene.
Player spawning is now handled by the NetworkManager instead of the
GameManager.
The NetworkManagerHUDCustom class is a modified version of Unity's
NetworkManagerHUD class
(https://bitbucket.org/Unity-Technologies/networking/src/2bdd9961092c4a73443c09694cff5dde9e56f9f1/Runtime/NetworkManagerHUD.cs?at=5.4&fileviewer=file-view-default),
adding special behaviour to handle the existing architecture of the game
(calling the ScreenManager's StartGame and EndGame methods, that then call
the GameManager events for creating and ending a game).
Initial commit
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

Added painting mask

A mask 2D texture is used to determine if a pixel that is being painted
on the canvas is inside the painting and should count towards the score
of the player.
To optimize efficiency, the texture is transformed into a bitset.

Make painted circle's radius abstract

scale of the ink drop.

complete in the future with parameters).
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Created parameter for canvas resolution

It is possible now to set the canvas resolution in the editor.
The texture size will be derived from this resolution, respecting the
aspect ratio of the canvas mesh / actor.
The resolution acts as if it is in world space: same resolution values
for canvases with different shapes or sizes will produce the same
quality on screen.

commit_list.message:
Implemented FSM Relax state

After Peak, the director enters Relax mode, where it stays for a minimum
amount of time or until all players are below max intensity (the latest
of both).
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Added Peak FSM state

When a player reaches max intensity, the director goes into Peak state.
During Peak, no more enemies spawn. Director doesn't leavePeak state
until a percentage of the enemies that are alive have been killed.
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Implemented BuildUp state exit transition

Added the transition from the BuildUp state, which checks if any player
has reached max intensity.
(For now, since we don't have the other States, it resets the BuildUp
state)
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Fixed a fatal crash in the AI Director

Fixed a crash that was caused by the state objects in the Finite State
Machine of the Director to be picked up by the garbage collector.

Since the UDirectorFSMState class is not an AActor, but a regular
UObject, in order for the garbage collector to not throw the instances
away, they must be referenced by an actor via a UPROPERTY. (They were
being referenced by the Director actor, but just not using said
specifier)
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Implemented player intensity tracking

Added the system that keeps track of player intensity for its use in the
AI Director when spawning enemies.
- The intensity of a player increases when being hit by an enemy.
- The intensity of a player increases when hitting a close enemy.
- The intensity of a player decays linearly over time.
- The intensity of a player locks at its maximum value during a fixed
period of time (the intensity value doesn't decay instantly upon
reaching max value)
commit_list.repo_description: Second big game group project. MSc & MA Computer Games & Entertainment

commit_list.message:
Added spawn rate build up

During build up state, the rate at which enemies are spawned
continuously increases up to the set maximum.

Merge branch 'FacultadInformatica-LinkedData/master'

StickBall2D - Experiment 2

Same as Experiment 1, with the introduction of a random initial angle.
This helps the neural network learn how to keep the stick balanced with
a more general range of angles.
In order for the stick to be balanced in situations with great angles,
the handle needs to have a higher velocity. Now the velocity can have
values higher than 1.0 up to an indicated maximum value.
Tweaked some evolution parameters
Changed readme file

Initial commit

Added UnityNEAT

StickBall2D - Experiment 1

Inputs:
- Vertical angle of the stick
- Current velocity of the ball

Output:
- Velocity of the handle, limited to magnitude = 1.0f

The ball is kept balanced, although the handle keeps on moving until it
goes out of the screen.

Next step:
- It should keep the stick balanced inside the window

Added random spawn position

Units are now created in a random position.
This way, the neural network learns to work at other heights (before it
wouldn’t be successful if it wasn’t at height 0).

StickBall2D - Experiment 3

The goal of this experiment is to try to keep the stick balanced inside
the white area. Whenever the stick or ball collides with the walls, a
penalty is given.

Inputs:
- Added the current position of the handle.

Created base for StickBall2D

Created base scene for the experiment.
Created prefab for the experiment.
Created basic controller.

Made learning process better

- Changed the learning process to use 5 random trials per generation.
This allows for each species in a generation to be tested multiple
times with 5 different random starting positions. This avoids a species
being the most fit due to its initial position being easier, which
makes the learning process better and more fair.
Added experiment description to readme
Added recalculated normals toggle
Added wireframe rendering

Fixed wireframe rendering

Used another method for wireframe rendering so it is applied to one
object only (by changing the meshTopology of the sphere mesh to use
lines instead of triangles)
Added camera orbit around planet
Implemented wave data edition in UI
Implemente new wave data creation
Implemented wave deletion

Added perlin noise terrain

Added a second sphere with terrain generated from perlin noise.

Added procedural color

Vertex colors can depend on height value
Allow for realistic material in oceans

Added wave combination

Added the possibility to sum various wave functions with different
parameters.

Fixed a bug in the wave formula, where the wave speed wasn’t being
applied correctly (it was dependent on the frequency).

Added wave data serialization

Wave data is now serialized to an xml file

Added offset paramenter

Blocking door integration

Deleted merge file

Deleted a .txt file generated by a merging conflict.
Added looping background music
Completed credits
Added an initial fade-in to game start

Fixed collisions and physics on feather

Made a proper mesh for the feather with working collisions settings.

Fixed a bug between eye and projectiles

Fixed a bug that caused the fired projectiles to affect AI navigation.
Added red overlay upon death by eye

Fixed death by eye while 9-tile puzzle opened

Death by eye now first forces the puzzle to close and then continues
with death animations.

Made NavMesh to generate dynamically on runtime

This allows for the navmesh to be rebuilt when several doors from
puzzles are opened, so the AI can now go through them.

Fixed a bug in day-night switch puzzle

Fixed a bug where the day-night switch puzzle wasn’t reenabling HUD
after camera animation.

Integrated main altar puzzle

Created final assets for the main altar puzzle

Hide the HUD when necessary

Camera animations (from death by eye, or in certain puzzles) now hide
the HUD properly.

Fixed an issue with consecutive player deaths

Fixed an issue that caused the player to get stuck dying multiple times
if it was killed by the eye in a corridor blocking the future path of
the eye.
Player now disables all collisions while dead.
Extended period of time the player is dead / knocked out.

Eye balance tuning

Tuned up eye movement speed and vision radius.
Fixed NavMesh settings. The eye is too big for the navmesh to generate
in certain corridors. However, the eye is already quite small. Rather
than making it even smaller, the capsule is reduced to allow navigation
through all corridors, but the actual mesh is kept the same size with
ignored collisions. This allow the eye to stay at a reasonable size
while functioning properly with the navmesh, at the expense of going
through some walls and corners (the frequency of this, as well as the
actual overlapping, are low enough to justify the workaround).

Integrated Eye mesh

Changed the Eye mesh to the final one (changed the given static mesh to
a skeletal mesh for use in character).
Adjusted NavMesh settings (mainly agent radius) to adjust to new size
of the eye.

Fixed collisions presets

Fixed collision response presets for the introduced custom collision
types Projectile and AI.

Polished 9 tile puzzle opening mechanism

Puzzle now opens with regular right click like other interactive
elements.

Integrated 9-tile puzzle

Puzzle now opens the door upon completion by sliding it up
(functionality independent of the dimensions of the door).

Integrated day/night switch

Created assets for pieces in the puzzle with the final meshes.

Fixed a bug in Piece Placing Sockets

Fixed a bug that caused a PiecePlacingSocket to activate even if it’s
piece had already been placed.

Refactored the classes created for day/night switch to be able to reuse

Added the ability for a placing socket to retrieve its piece upon
interacting with it.

Implemented pieces for day/night switch.

Day/night switch requires that three pieces are placed.
Player can set said pieces by putting them in their required place.

Added camera animation to day/night switch

Upon switch, view changes to a custom camera that gives a high view of
the map.
Added a white fade in and out to cover the streaming levels switch.

Added lighting scenarios and day/night switch

Added the two streaming levels (“sublevels”) for the day and night
scenarios (as lighting scenarios for separate lighting builds).
Implemented a very simplistic day/night switch to test the loading and

Merge pull request #15 from parmandorc/trap-blocking-door

Block a door with falling rocks when the player overlaps for the first time an specific trigger (functional pass)

Fixed Eye movement outside pyramid

The Eye is now properly blocked in the entrance of the pyramid, using a
Blocking Volume that only blocks the newly added object type ‘AI’
(which is the same as ‘Pawn’ for all other purposes).
The Eye keeps on chasing the player but doesn’t step out of the pyramid.
This fixes the previous behaviour, where the Eye would randomly lose
vision of the player when stepped out of the pyramid, and sometimes
even successfully follow them outside of the NavMesh, with
unpredictable results.

Fixed the rotation animation before killing the player

Fixed the rotation so it start at the proper position, whereas it was
starting in its projection onto the horizontal plane.

Eye no longer chases player after dying

Eye stays looking at the player until the player’s screen has gone
black, then no longer chases them and resumes its patrolling behaviour.

Implemented player death and respawn

The eye now fires the Kill event of the player after rotating them.
Death events launches a fade to black animation. This is followed by
the respawn process, which consists on a fade back and re-enabling of
control input.

Fixed rotation timeline

Fixed the timeline for rotating the player towards the eye.

Added player death by eye

They eye now kills / knocks out the player when he catches him.
Player loses input control, and they are turned towards the eye.

Integrated eye in the new map

Added the eye, navmesh and waypoints to the scene.
Corrected navmesh generation in stairs.

Implement logic for puzzle completion

Implemented the method that checks whether the puzzle has been solved.

Implement tile interchange

Added the logic for interchanging the two selected tiles.

Added selection of tiles.

Implemented the selection and deselection of tiles, which offset their
position slightly to highlight the selected ones.
Added the structure against which to check whether the tiles are in the
correct position to open the door.

Puzzle tiles & open/close puzzle events

Implemented events to open/close the puzzle interaction (the camera
locks onto the puzzle, input for the player actor is disabled and mouse
input is unlocked).

Merge pull request #9 from parmandorc/controls

Controls: Pick up, drop and throw
Completed instructions in README.md
Corrected typos in README.md file

Updated README.md

Added instructions to edit the project in Unreal and make commits (aimed at artist especially).

Changed player detection for agro check

The agent now only detects the player as in vision range if it is in
front of them (currently 90º vision half angle), or if they are really
close.

Optimized simple agro check

Due to the fact that the game is single player and there is only one
enemy AI agent, there is no sense in performing a Multi Sphere Trace.
Instead, it is enough to check the distance of the player to the agent,
and then perform the visibility check by just one line trace.

Implemented patrolling behaviour

The AI agent is now able to patrol through a cyclic set of waypoints in
the scene whenever it is not chasing the player.
Simplified implementation of the chasing behaviour (using existing
methods instead of the ones created).

Files reestructure

Moved AI related files to a specific Eye subfolder

Added basic following behaviour

Implemented a following behavior, where the AI agent will follow the
player when in distance and in sight. If they lose sight of the player,
they will move to their last known location, wait and move back to
their original location.

Added assets for AI

Added the needed assets for AI, as well as a navMesh to the scene.
